comments.commentBody: Tim B, the NSA shades are a not for profit hue unless the off the hook contracting company responsible for divulging state secrets through their employee is under scrutiny now. Facebook, google, credit card companies and giant telecoms are a far greater privacy concern than the Federal government, Their in business to profit from selling our information.

David, one can opt out of Facebook, Twitter, Google, credit card companies, et al by not joining Facebook or Twitter, by using a search engine other than Google, and by not having a credit card. And even if one chooses to join those sites or have a credit card, none of those entities have the power to charge you with crimes and send you to jail.

One cannot opt out of NSA and other government searches of one's life, and they do have the power to charge you with a crime and drastically interfere with your life, even send you to jail.

I know which group I consider more dangerous.
Shades of police statism, Tim B. Are we really there?

'the first would make everyone’s news feed searchable'

Shades of the NSA, many people openly share their political likes and dislikes on Facebook. This sounds like yet another huge database being assembled for future use. Facebook has openly admitted that they have provided reams of information to the vast and growing surveillance apparatus of our government, of course at government request.

As with the hounding (and worse) or anti-war demonstrators and those called 'pacifists' at the time of the Vietnam War, or those who have some admiration for groups in our time such as Earth First, what will happen with all of this information being gathered?

As with government, are we all supposed to just accept the mantra "you can trust us"? Even the beginnings of Facebook are tinged with scandal and corruption, at least as Zuckerberg is portrayed in The Social Network. Certainly there is dramatic interpretation in the movie, as is always the case.

But I wouldn't trust this man with my checkbook, or my privacy.

"So the Alamo was a fight for slavery in Texas?"

Land and cattle thieving by white, southern, illegal aliens.
Bravo as usual. http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/19/us/politics/texans-stick-with-cruz-des...
Wishful thinking that. Unfortunately very very few Mexican-Americans vote. It will be 20 years before Texas turns blue.

Before Texas was a Republic it was a Mexican Territory, with a population of just 4000 Tejanos.

By 1824 The Mexican Government - desperate to populate the region - invited Americans to settle the region, under the requirement and assumption that the settlers would learn Spanish, convert to Roman Catholicism, and be loyal to the Mexican Government.

By 1832, the number of American settlers was over 30,000 and very few of them obeyed any of the three requirements, and most had also brought slavery into Texas, which was against Mexican Law.

When the Mexican government began to enforce the ban on slavery, desire for secession reached its peak, eventually leading to the Texas Revolution, and defacto Texan Independence by the interloping settlers.

It's time for Mexican Americans to reclaim Texas via a massive voter registration and voter turnout on November 4, 2014.

The Good Old Boys of Texas have trashed Texas and the United States for far too long.

And this country will take two to three decades to recover from the Texas nightmare known as George W. Bush.

Without Texas elevating that fraternity boy to governor, the United States would have been spared its modern Dark Age.

We will never forget what Good Old Boy Texas did to the United States of America and the world with George W. Bush.

Mexican-Americans voting on November 4, 2014 will thankfully give us Governor-Elect Wendy Davis.
Of course, you and I know that "ultra-conservative", if we had any such people, would be the opposite of what they are.  "Ultramontane", in the 16th-century sense (appropriately), is closer.
Thanks, all of you, for your kind remarks.  You're a terrific group and I love the good-natured, intelligent and witty banter you all engage in.  Enjoy your weekend!

Dave! Dave!
Come back, Dave!

(We really mean that.)
RIA, I'm just a fair piano and guitar player.  And MOL, thanks for alluding to one of my favorite films.  I may yet ride back into the valley.

Great puzzle, and 35 down (although I believe it should be Mmm, Mmm good, not Mm Mm good), brought a smile to my face for two reasons.  I sang on a number of those spots during my career as a jingle singer in NYC, and on a totally different note (I'll try to keep this short), once long ago during a round of golf I scored a hole-in-one playing on my knees, and the story made its way to Sports Illustrated.  The article ended, "Ragaini...pocketed the $50 and ambled off, probably rubbing his knees and almost certainly humming M-m-m, M-m-m Good".
Yeah, great idea, just play right into their crazy hands.  Sheesh, and I thought our Texas Republicans were nutty.
Ah, I don't know about that plan. Can they take LA with 'em? Please?

But what would we do about all the ports and oil refineries?

We could change the Dallas Cowboys to the Dallas Vaqueros or Gauchos.

Why not encourage Texas to secede? That way our southern border fence would be straighter, with the exception of the Red River and a bit of the Louisiana border, and it would be easier to defend against illegal immigrants or tourists from Texas. Take the U.S. military troops from their Texas forts and bases and posts and line them up along the U.S. side of the border, together with the border drones and other military weapons. Our Texas naval bases could relocate to the Red River and the Marines to eastern Louisiana. It's a win-win for both countries.

Not only that, he'd be singing it in Spanish for the Spanish King.  The English at the time of the Revolution has outlawed Westward expansion past the Alleghenies, in order to promote peace on the Frontier without fighting the Indians, a major issue at the time.  Texas would have had no Alamo.
Now there's an idea the full House and full Senate should agree on!

I'd bet my bottom dollar that if Texas did somehow secede, El Paso County and other west Texas regions would beg for New Mexico to take them on. East and West Texas are somewhat different demographically and politically. (I'm a transplanted El Pasoan.)

Alex in Texas,

If the people of Texas keep electing loonies, then maybe it's time to rethink where you live.

If you have children in public schools, do you really want their curriculum leveraged by non-educators who believe creationism is indisputable fact?

Do you want to live in a state that would limit a woman's access to reproductive health care...and I don't just mean abortion.

Do you want to live in a state where guns are freely available in all shapes, sizes, and calibers to anyone who feels like owning one?

If you are having issues with any of these along with the myriad of other right fringe issues, and the opposition party is unable to mount a successful campaign to move closer to the center of things for the entire state, moving might be a serious consideration.

The cry for secession is heard coming _from_ Texas. Maybe it's time to let the state vote on it. It is possible, that's what the majority of Texans want.

The WP

Just between us chickens, I'm rooting for secession.

Amazement at Texan's over-inflated self-esteem never ceases; they all believe that the rest of us value their opinions above all others...as if.

Is it the air? The water? Or something they serve in school lunch? People who should be outraged by racist and anti-diversity, sorta shrug and give Texas a pass.

Okay. Fair enough. Let's give Texas a pass. Pass 'em right outta the USA. If they want to teach creationism as science and their version of Obamacare outcome as math, let 'em. We don't need their cockamamie scores on our benchmarks.

Hand 'em the keys to their capitol, then remove all Federal support and functions from inside the walls they will create to keep the rest of America out. No social security, no medicare or medicaid, no price supports, no favored nation status. No funding, no nothing. Require a visa to keep the undesirables (ie Texans) from getting in to the rest of the US. It's only fair.

Excise Texas. That's the first plan I've heard of that might be useful.

Just make that state of cranial contusion just go away.

http://wifelyperson.blogspot.com/

As one of the leading pop culture whiners, I am going to demur on that complaint tonight. Sure, plenty of such clues. But they were balanced with some occasional gimmes. The really hard problems were the obscure (and not so obscure) senators and presidential candidates.

There was some very clever misdirection in this puzzle. I put in RPI instantly and could never get away from it. This led to more difficulties on the cross-referenced clue. I think that single three letter mistake was the hardest part of the puzzle for me. It just sat in a very bad place.

I'm okay with my DNF today. This was a clever and difficult puzzle that was way out of my wheelhouse. Maybe in a couple more years of solving. Still irritated about not getting space jam/coca cola.
Occasionally I'll do 80, but NAUT NINETY. That, and KEVIN, cured me of RPI.

I got chunks of this puzzle, but I pretty much had the same experience. I got things in the NE and SE corners--filled those first--but after that it just petered out.

JOHNNYCAKES? Remind me never to go to Rhode Island.

Boy, I didn't care much for this puzzle.  Too many clues for pop culture I didn't pay attention to in my misbegotten youth, obscure places, obscure historical figures, etc.  Schmutz is not slang.  It is German, or Yiddish.   Okay, I did like the SE corner.

Austin may be a blue island in a sea of red, but we are gaining strength. I'm a third generation Texan, and voted for Ronald Reagan and Bush, Sr., but I also voted twice for President Obama. The times they are a-changing. Count on it. After the shutdown, I would vote for a Democratic yellow dog over any Republican.

Old white man in Austin

I'll just mention that Texas has no "Lock" on crazy politicians.

Michele Bachmann
Rick Santorum
Bobby Jindal
Mitch McConnell
Sarah Palin

None of them are from Texas and if they aren't just as bat[expletive] crazy as any of those listed (and you missed the wonderful Blake Farenthold who is "resisting Obamacare with all his might to 'protect' us from it's harmful effects -- list ALL the crazy, please) then I'm a native Texan (Born in California, liberal and stuck here in Texas)

I think we should make it a national law that Gerrymandering be considered treason.

I know some real nice reasonable Texans including business owners in Texas, but for the life of me, when meeting the general public down there and listening to their political opinions, I can't understand where they are coming from and logic seems to have completely be a foreign language to them.  I live in a state that has a larger voting percentage for Republicans than Texas and yet, even my neighbors (hard rock traditional conservative scandanavian Lutherans) can't understand Texans either.  They are like aliens in their political views and don't come anywhere near what we call conservative up here. Alas, as I told my friends down there, come visit us up here or in some other state.  Our family will never visit or do business in Texas again.  If they secede, we wouldn't miss them at all.

I must comment on your opening sentence, manfred marcus: Texas politicians are not the most uninformed and ignorant folks; the Texans who voted for them are. I bet most of the politicians, when the lights are out and they're in bed with their thoughts, chortle at how it is easy to "work" the voters. These guys are becoming rich men. Ignorant? Ignorant as a fox.
.. not to mention belief in demonic possession.
It's the ignorant voters as you noted.

Texan politicians are probably some of the most uninformed and willfully ignorant folks, unashamed of their prejudices; and a governor that has not learned anything since his failed run for the presidency. The other smart aleck, canadian-born pompous rubble rouser, left his supposed 'smartness' at Harvard's door, still with pretenses for glory after the chaos he engendered. You have to wonder what's the matter with texans to have voted these guys in (to begin with). Could it be their school system (and books,  denying science, evolution and climate change, and civics, and common sense, and the art of compromise)?

@Mary

You're right. There is that. The more immediate hit millions will feel is the end of the stimulus money added to SNAP through the Recovery Act. That ends November 1. Anyone who is currently on SNAP will see a reduction to $1.40 per meal. Other than the Dems and the President, no one will fend for the hungry. I've not seen anything on this other than a report from the CBPP.

Then... There is the $24 billion that Congressional TeaParty Republicans blew over the shutdown. How many jobs could we have created with that money? Our president is best placed to highlight that fact and drive the point home in a state by state tour.

Then... there is the sequester cuts to come after the first of the year. How many Americans even know what they are and how they will be affected?

Getting ready for Election 2014 by putting all of these issues in the public consciousness and keeping them there has to take first priority.

http://www.cbpp.org/cms/?fa=view&id=3899
"Ah feel your pain."

This government shutdown was so unnecessary. I am a transplant Texan. If Texas feels so proud of Ted Cruz, maybe we should not accept the transfer of wealth from blue states to Texas. Not. I, for one, wish I didn’t have to live among people this nutty. My district is so Gerrymandered, I will never be represented by someone sane. Maybe if we can move all nuts in the country to Texas, sane people can move out, and Texas can finally secede.

Getting to a REST STOP without taking an EXIT would be even funnier!

Yes, it was tough, but I finished with only JARJAR x ANAS in doubt.

WHATSUPG was a new one on me and I suspected a rebus where the G fit for GOT OVER. Two-way rebus?

5. No one should be expected to know the names of US Senators. ...unless you lived in the state while they served!

@Kevin

I thought you'd get a kick out of that... :-)

A couple of facts here:

1. Texas is second only to California in the amount of revenue sent to the federal government. We are not a nanny-state.

2. An "unholy horde" did not illegally immigrate to Mexico. Mexico was bankrupt after their war with Spain and *invited* immigration to the newly formed Mexican state of Tejas since Mexico couldn't afford to form a militia for the protection of that state. Stephen F. Austin received a land grant from the Mexican government in 1822 and settled the first 300 colonists from the United States. They were the "rightful" property owners, according to the Mexican government. The war began when President Bustamante reneged on the contract's provision of waiving of taxes for ten years and imposed steep tariffs on goods imported from the United States. Unfortunately, the prohibition of slavery by the Mexican government was also a factor.

3. With respect to Governor Perry, you are absolutely correct.

I understand your animosity to Ted Cruz and the other stellar politicians from Texas, I share it completely. Just please keep your facts straight and criticize Texas for the reasons it deserves . Believe me, there are plenty without resorting to inaccurate ad hominem attacks.

Very good! Texas is barely over the not-nannied line at about 97 cents of every federal dollar coming back to the state.

Fort Hood is the largest employer in Texas and has created an entire city around its existence.

Perry brags about "creating" jobs in Texas which is code for allowing employers in other states to move to Texas so they can treat employees like Chinese factory workers.

I wish more Hispanics in the state would "Remember the Alamo", when an unholy horde of cattle-thieving land-grabbers illegally emigrated into Mexican territory and did to the rightful property owners what Texans do to the rest of us today.

What it will take to end the Hastert rule is restoring a sense of responsibility (to the country, not just constituents) among the GOP.  With the amount of money being thrown at the far right to do exactly what it's currently doing, that's going to take a while.

G -- The GOP is not "responsible to constituents" either.

It is responsible only to donors. Its big money comes from a radical fringe, and it serves that.

Nobody else is going to pay for them. They can't change. They won't. They are history.

The interesting question is how they will be replaced.

Full exploitation of victory is even more important than winning the victory itself. The big payoff from a win comes from keeping them on the run.

It is wonderful that Obama is staying on them, driving this.

Immigration is a good place to push. However, I wonder if changing the subject to immigration is the best way to exploit the win on the shutdown.

While Obama won that fight, what he won is that we did not default today, our shutdown ended after 16 days. We are set to do it all over again in three months. To me, that means the win has not yet been exploited to end that fight.

Then again, maybe Obama feels the best way to exploit it is to let them do it again and lose again. Maybe it will take that to end the Hastert Rule and the use of our national interests as a partisan political hostage. That is a painful thought.

This recent round of Tea Party propaganda made me remember something said by the character, Ernestine Coleman, in Philip Roth's The Human Stainn:

"But the danger with hatred is, once you start in on it, you get a hundred times more than you bargained for. Once you start, you can't stop. I don't know anything harder to control than hating. Easier to kick drinking than to master hate."

Whilst the Dems may not have written legislation taking away food from the hungry, they sure were more than willing to go along with it. As for the travel expenses for families of fallen soldiers, here too they did nothing to stop the practice. I donated many airline miles so our soldiers could get home for their leave since "our" Dems and GOP felt it was only necessary to pay for them to get to Dallas, Atlanta, or New York or wherever they first reached US soil. Evil persists because good men and women remain seated and silent. The current crop of DEMs are the lesser of 2 evils.

The shutdown disaster, harmful as it was, was a net benefit to the Democratic Party.

We are now united behind the President, as opposed to a month or more ago when we were divided by the President's stances on surveillance and Syria.

We are stronger now and in a better position to fight the hatred and negativity of the hard right.

Let's get down to business and just do it!

Hatred is a powerful emotion. We've seen how it got out the vote for the GOP in 2010, just two years after crushing defeat in 2008.

The Republican hate machine is already whipping up the ranks with their new false message that President Obama and the Democrats shut down the government to destroy the Republican Party along with the Tea Party.

Lies and hate backed by big money fanatics like the Kochs, Club for Growth & Heritage Action - that's how Republicans win elections.

Democrats can't let 2014 become a rerun of 2010. They need to correct the record now and every day until the next election and they also need to call out the MSM every time they repeat a phony Republican talking point.

@xxx

It would be foolish and dangerous to consider them anything other than lunatic and fringe. None of them have anything in their body of work in Congress to justify calling them capable of anything other than going in front of cameras and spouting off the most ridiculous things the world has ever heard.

Gohmert and Bachmann went to Egypt and in the press conference they gave, compared General Sissi to George Washington and said the “bloodthirsty Muslim Brothers” want to “destabilize things” and seek “that large caliphate.”

No. It's going to be a while until a Republican takes the White House. A very long while.

http://www.politico.com/blogs/media/2013/09/bachmann-gohmert-kings-bizar...
Thank you. Well said.

@MJones

Great points! Prop-13 caused some problems but did significantly more good than harm in general.

Prop-13 frees countless families from being enslaved by property value and the all-mighty dollar. We have the freedom to make tough decisions that benefit our families. For example, keeping a long time family home for an aging parent; a dying loved one or our children and even grandchildren.

Quit bad-mouthing Prop 13 indeed.
Maybe should be a light tax on properties that have hugely increased in value  when they sell though, like a capital gains tax.

Don't blame Prop 13 for the condition of California's governments. Although I think commercial real estate should have been exempt from Prop 13, I think Prop 13 deserves credit for preserving our housing stock and viable communities. It is responsible for the many stable, well kept neighborhoods, especially in dense cities with fantastic economies like San Francisco. And we have universal health care and good public transit for America.

There is no way that seniors could have stayed near their children as they aged without Prop 13! Props 13 kept and keeps income tax levels at reasonable rates for homeowners. So as the fantastically successful dot com and now Google/Facebook/Silicon Valley in general led to young people becoming millionaires and billionaires overnight, these Googleaires bid up the cost of ordinary middle class houses to the highest in the nation. I live in a 1800 SF admittedly lovely house on a 25 x 75 lot (with admittedly a spectacular view) that I paid 1/4 of the current market value for just 10 years ago! It is now worth over $2.5 million conservatively, even I were willing to see it. Thanks to Prop 13, my taxes have not increased by a factor of 5 or I would have to move. It's hard enough to make ends meet as your income drops as you grow older.

I hear many complaints in places with good economies like the suburbs of New York City, where senior have a terrible problem with vastly property tax increases. It's very sad.

Quit bad mouthing Prop 13.

I just moved from an apartment building where there are multiple 3-generation Latino families, typically 5-6 people, living cramped together into tiny studio apartments.

This is certainly not the " high life" (or immense wealth) that you speak of,but rather the life of poverty. You must be living in some alternate universe (or isolated bubble) where you get this completely false and fantasized information. An objective fact check, grounded in the real world, would be good to open your eyes to the real situation of so-called "minorities" living in these cities.

You sound like you hate California.

You seem to think that nerds fiddling with computers in SF or movie producers fiddling with cameras in LA are causing farm workers in the the central valley to be poor. I guess those two cities control the price of vegetables, huh?

In CA we pride ourself on not only being industrious but also humane. The notion that we spend huge amounts of money on illegal immigrants is the fantasy of xenophobes and bigots, not the reality on the ground.

We have welfare but we also have taxes that pay for it. The rich are not the problem but the source of large amounts of tax revenue.

And those taxes are easily avoidable: all you need to do is leave.

I was born and raised in Southern California and lived there all my life until 3 years ago when at 55 I realized that California is a lost cause.

It is broken, it has a one party system which fails the people.

I lived in Long Beach, and the entire Southern Ca area had become unrecognizable to me. Graffiti everywhere, high crime, high taxes, bad (horrible!) schools where 50% and higher drop out (in the LA school district).

Traffic is a nightmare, roads are falling apart, everything that the government is taxing the people for is falling apart.

I asked myself the question of what really was the benefit of staying in California? Taxes were so high, and I received no benefits from the state. Those things that should have been taken care of by government:

roads
schools
police
fire

Were falling apart and every year that any cuts were ever proposed the state government would cut the police and fire departments instead of cutting those programs that the state should never be involved in.

The only benefit left for me in California was the mild weather (which the government doesn't control). But when I compared the cost of living and job opportunities, California lost out completely.

As a Californian, I fail to understand how our broken government can be a model for anybody.

The reason I haven't left the state yet is primarily emotional because this state has given me so much. If my decision of staying were based only on the political system, I would have left many years ago. I can hardly see the virtue in a one party system, which is what we have here. Republicans here would be Democrats in Texas. Arnold or Mr Cannella are indistinguishable from the Democrats. Arnold particularly refused to support or defend Prop 8 well before Obama "evolved".

Our state is dying a slow death. It keeps going because of its glorious past but its future is clouded. Over the last 20 years it has become de facto a feudal society. A significant portion of the population lives in near poverty. Our state spends untold amounts of money in benefits for illegal immigrants to keep their family members voting for the Democrats. At the same time a minority who lives in Los Angeles or the San Francisco Bay Area is immensely wealthy. This situation, in which a significant portion of the population is kept poor and ignorant so that a minority can enjoy the high life, is hardly a model for a successful society. Don't take me wrong., I am against wealth redistribution but if other states were to become as California socially and politically, our country would in a path to become Greece in less than 10 years.

I disagree. Having lived here the whole time in question, I can say it was frustrating beyond belief to have the California budget held hostage year after year. Even though the Democrats had the majority in most of the State legislature, it was not a two-thirds majority and the Republicans were able to keep any of the budget reforms they didn't like from passing into law. Finally, the recently-elected Governor Brown drummed up enough support among the public to pass important initiatives to break through the impasse, including removing the 2/3 majority requirement for spending.

It's not what everyone wants on any side, but that plus the other measures mentioned in the article did rescue us from the same sort of totally one-sided "austerity" that's now being attempted to bring our whole country down.

The previous commenter was correct that now we have to do a similar thing for allowing taxes to be raised by the State legislatures. Meanwhile the 2012 initiative also passed by voters, Proposition 30, did some emergency triage by raising a combination of slightly higher income taxes for the wealthy and a slight increase in statewide sales tax. We still had to accept terrible cuts to essential services, but we had reached the bone and these measures saved the body.

It _is_ possible to break through an impossible-looking situation by compromise and common sense. We don't have to keep caving in until our whole government is destroyed.

We basically live in a one-party system. The Dem party is the party of government; they now cover the moderate, conservative (yes), and sometimes even liberal portions of the spectrum--i.e., the spectrum once covered by the two parties. The Republican "party" has no meaningful role in government whatsoever. They exist to plunder and obstruct.

Maryland is another good example.

If the GOP would get out of the way of an economic resurgence for the US, it would fade into relative insignificance. Of course, thenthey could not constantly din about the debt and use it as the only stalking horse they have left for doing in Obama, government, minorities, the 99%, women and gays. Fie on those Tea Party fanatics, but especially those cynical 1 percenters (Koch et al.) who fund them and demagogues like Cruz who manipulate them.

Is there really any similarity between the current Republican Party and that of Lincoln? Even Reagan wouldn't stand a chance in today's GOP.

The Republican Party seems to have become almost exclusively the party of money and business, to the exclusion of everything else, and the Democratic Party is a mix of what the two parties used to be.

Independently drawn districts does seem to be the key. Thinking it is reasonable to have districts which are homogenous can be taken to the absurd level that my district is my side of the bed, and we're all members of Congress.

Rather than curbing partisanship, it sounds as if California has essentially curbed the power of the "party of mean." It's astounding that this once Grand Old Party which is anti feeding people in need, anti minority voting rights, anti a woman's right to choose, anti reasonable immigration reform--and pro "winning" at all costs is the same party that birthed the passions and compassion of an Abraham Lincoln.

Ideally, similar to California, national political transformation is required so we can once again have two humane stable/rational political parties and points of view. And bottom line, that means attracting and voting for open constructive progressive positive political minds, ignoring and eventually purging closed limited regressive ones, and in the process finally get back "the right stuff"--the wisdom, heart and soul stuff that makes a nation great, even exceiptional.

Rita, I think you are comparing reality to a perfect world that does not exist. When I was in high school in the early 90's, we minimized using the restroom at all and no one but the football team dared to shower in the locker room. Athletes all had to make the tryout. If they're good enough to help the team win, who cared about anything else. And if they were just "diversity" athletes, they were relegated to "junior varsity."

As for parents, a lot of my classmates were living with aunts, uncles, grandparents, step parents, parents with 3 jobs, or just by themselves. I doubt most would prefer to have no parents than three parents. But by and large, most of us grew up to be well-adjusted adults.

Come to think it, perhaps it is the coming of age of my generation, who witnessed Pete Wilson-style Republicanism, LA Riots, and the defense-cut recession, that is adding our voice of reason and moderation to state politics.
